responses: That is partly true. High blood sugar, which is a symptom of uncontrolled diabetes, can cause peripheral vascular disease, which refers to damage to the nerves and arteries in your limbs. This can result in not feeling temperature difference in your extremities, and numbness and weakness in your limbs. Uncontrolled diabetes can also sometimes cause a loss of feeling in the tip of the toes or the tip of the fingers (particularly in the case of Type 2 Diabetes), as the nerves responsible for sensory perception are damaged. These are all dangerous conditions, and they can lead to limb damage and even tissue loss. Managing diabetes with the proper medical and lifestyle treatments can help to control the disease, thus preventing this kind of damage.

It’s true that uncontrolled diabetes can also cause tissues and organs to stop receiving adequate nutrients and oxygen from the blood, which over time can lead to poor circulation and reduced oxygen levels. If this happens, amputations may become necessary if the tissue of the affected part of the body suffers extensive damage from poor circulation. However, if the diabetes is properly managed with a healthy diet and a controlled, active lifestyle this is much less likely to happen.
